thread.title: These are the beaches from hell
thread.title_full: These are the beaches from hell

title: These are the beaches from hell
text:
What are these? Just like sardines ... people sunbathe at Levante Beach in Benidorm, Spain. Picture: Getty Source: Getty Images 
AS WINTER sets in and temperatures plummet, we begin to yearn for sunnier skies. Huddled over the heater and wearing too many layers we imagine lying on that beach in Spain or sailing around the Amalfi Coast and popping into Positano for lunch, but is it really all it’s cracked up to be? 
People were literally packed like sardines onto Levante beach in Benidorm. According to the latest records over 29.2 million tourists visited Spain in June. People sunbathe at Levante Beach in Benidorm, Spain. Picture: Getty Source: Getty Images 
In France, Parisians who haven’t travelled South for their holidays can pull up a lounge and sunbake on a temporary, tiny stretch of sand along the banks of the River Seine Parisians and tourists stroll on pathway of Paris-Plage installation along banks of River Seine in Paris. Picture: AP Source: AP 
What about a trip to Asia? In Qingdao city, in East China’s Shandong province the whole beach is covered in algae and has been every summer for the last eight years. The bright green stuff has blanketed at least 13,500 square miles of ocean this summer. An algae-covered beach in Qingdao city, east China's Shandong province. Picture: Splash Source: Splash News Australia 
To protect from the algae as well as jelly fish stings and UV rays, many locals have taken to wearing ‘face-kinis’ with their full length swimmers. A Chinese woman and her daughter wear face-kinis as they leave the water at the beach on the Yellow Sea in Qingdao, China. Picture: Getty Source: Supplied 
Or what about a trip to the Caribbean? Maho beach on the idyllic island of St Maarten sits directly at the end of the tiny runway of the island’s Princess Juliana International Airport. The tranquil setting is routinely disrupted by incoming Boeing 747’s carrying new sun seekers from around the world. Tourists can be seen reaching up as if to try and grab the planes — while others seem completely unmoved by the noisy and imposing intrusion. And despite looking like a movie disaster waiting to happen, the safety record is impeccable. But an ominous sign does warn tourists daft enough to stand at the end of the runway that the giant jets blast is enough to sweep them off their feet — and potentially injure or even kill them. Sunset Beach by Princess Juliana International Airport. Tourists can casually grab a tan on this idyllic Caribbean beach and do a spot of plane watching all at the same time. Picture: Splash Source: Supplied 
Don’t know about you but I think I’ll just rug up and have a clack down to Bondi Beach and wait patiently for spring to arrive.
